response.answer_text: Interesting that all the answers so far do not in any way reflect what sociopaths themselves have had to say about this. They say that they indeed can. I am more inclined to believe their personal experience than conjecture. Athena Walker's answer to Can a sociopath love? Sociopaths can yes. Here I will insert a brief description of sociopathy that will then assist with the rest of the answer. Athena Walker's answer to Is it true that sociopaths don’t lack empathy but lacks remorse and guilt? I read it somewhere in sociopathworld.com. Sociopaths do not have an absolute lack of empathy. However, this is not an AHA!! moment where you can say, I KNEW IT!! They just don’t want to be nice people. Those wily bastards!! Okay, in fairness I have no idea if you thought that at all, but someone reading this might, so, you know, disclaimer. What it means is this. As sociopaths have the neural map of a neurotypical person in an fMRI machine, they are not lacking in, nor do they have differences in the brain that are apparent as psychopaths do, they have the grey matter necessary to experience what empathy is. Here is the massive difference from neurotypical responses, from sociopathic ones. When the sociopathy is formed, the person experiencing whatever the causative agent is tends to shut off their access to the emotions like affection, desire for attention, empathy, anything that would make them outwardly dependent and turn insularly. While the pathways are still there, they are no longer used. Think of it this way. If you have a child that you never speak to, the neurons of the brain responsible for language get pruned away. The less experience with it, the more stunted the ability to learn language becomes. Often this is irreversible. The child will have difficulty with communication for the rest of their life assuming that their lack of exposure to language was chronic and ongoing. Apply this lesson to sociopathy and what they are cutting themselves off from. The neurons that are responsible for bonding, empathy, affection, love, are pruned away. They have the pathways, but instead of a eight lane highway, they now have a two way, single lane, mountain pass. It’s treacherous and unpredictable. You have no idea what is going to successfully traverse this pass, and what is going over the edge, never to be seen again. The ability for empathy is there. The communication of it however is not like a neurotypical person. It’s difficult to navigate and get through from origin to manifestation. Also, it doesn’t necessarily trigger for a person. It is just as likely, if not more so in some cases, for it to trigger for a character in a book over a live person. The character in the book, or perhaps a movie, has no actual impact on the sociopath’s life. They cannot cause them harm in any way. There is a safety to that person being locked away on paper, or behind a glass screen. They can allow themselves to experience that person’s life more fully and without reservation because it’s separate. While they look fully capable on brain scans, and in some instances in their life, it would be a mistake to assume that this means that empathy is an emotion that is at their fingertips that they are ignoring. There is a much larger picture at work. Okay, now that you have a working understanding of the brain of a sociopath, yup, replace love with empathy, it is possible. It’s not always available, it’s not always deep, sometimes it’s very deep, it depends. Sociopathy is a very complex condition. It’s not a straight forward, they have no empathy and are demons kind of condition, like many people would like to have them defined as. Two great answers on this were provided by Quora writer Corey Reaux-Savonte. Corey Reaux-Savonte's answer to What is a sociopath? Corey Reaux-Savonte's answer to Could a sociopath stay loyal in a relationship? I highly recommend them both.

What would make them exciting? Not a HFS trait. Can a sociopath love? That’s a tricky question. I can act like I’m in love with someone. I play the part well. However it’s only an act. I don’t feel anything towards the people I date or am in a relationship with. I select them because of their looks, then I charm them, and fuck them stupid. I break up with them out of nowhere and don’t give a good reason for doing so. It breaks them.  I think I’ve only experienced emotional love with a single person. It wasn’t the typical type of love, though. In a way, it was very childish. I care about them and wanted to help and protect them. They are my favorite thing. I care about them the way a toddler might care about a toy they have. I don’t like people messing with my things. Around 17 I was curious if I really cared for this person. I would make up scenarios in my mind to see how I would react if something bad happened to them. I imagined them being bullied. It ruffled my feathers. I was a little irritated. I imagined them emotionally broken. I didn’t like that. Lastly, I imagined something awful. (I’m not gonna type it out.) The make believe scenario in my head was enough for me to experience the most intense rage I’ve ever felt. I felt my body heat up from anger. I could hear my heart pumping loudly in my ears and feel an insane amount of adrenaline coursing through my body. I’ve never felt anything like it before. It took a while for me to calm down. It took 30 minutes, if I remember correctly.  It’s an extremely possessive type of love, if you can even call it that.

Thoughts from a married sociopath. These Are the 7 Types of Love Everyone seems to be hankering after romantic love, but few of us realize that far from being timeless and universal, romantic love is in fact a modern construct, one that emerged in tandem with the novel. The article briefly describes the seven types of love. Despite what many have stated, I believe most, if not all, sociopaths have the capacity to love. Briefly glossing over many of the answers that sociopaths have written, there is this theme among many that state, “I don’t think I can fall in love.”. Interesting. This to me seems to highlight the trust issues that many a sociopath have. The ones who said I don’t think are not willing to risk it, so therefore they say no way, I can’t do it. Self-limiting, I suppose. “I don’t think” is not the same as I can’t; it’s a conscious choice one makes. As for me, I am learning to love. The Eros type love, romantic type love, is what I think this question is aimed at. At any rate, that type of love falls off as a couple spends any significant length of time together, usually greater than about two years. It’s similar to the shiny, new object syndrome that loses its luster, so to speak. (Avoid Shiny Object Syndrome in Your Relationship) So it is with Eros love. For me, I’ve never been romantic. I have always been highly sexually attracted toward my wife. Compliments paid to her physical beauty. And so on. But not the dope who sprinkles rose pedals on the floor and candles everywhere. Too much wasted time and someone has to pick that shit up after, is how I see it. A waste. It doesn’t makes sense to me. But does that mean we can’t share a moment watching a sunset or some shit like that? Not my cup of tea, but willing to do it for her. Isn’t that love? Sacrificing for the other person. So out with the Eros love. Next up is the practical love. This called Pragma love: Pragma is a kind of practical love founded on reason or duty and one’s longer-term interests. Sexual attraction takes a back seat in favour of personal qualities and compatibilities, shared goals, and making it work This is the type of love that I have always had for my wife. It’s the type I will always have for my wife. Since I am selfish, sexual attraction does not take a back seat. It has, is, and will remain prominent. Pragma is the type of love that all successful relationships will be based on: long-term, shared goals, and making it work. The pre-determination to stick it out. Sociopaths can and have the capability to display and honor this type of love. The short-sightedness, impulsive, and immediate gratification we seek may challenge this type of practical love, but if one can display impulse control this practical love can be held intact and lead to a lasting relationship. Again, this is love. I’ve been with my wife 20 years, married 18. Not all glorious, as it is expected when one is of my type. I’ve experienced the Eros love (diminished intensity) in conjunction with pragma love. But what I have really learned over the last 5–6 years and am continuing to learn is how to love my wife the way she wants to be loved. How to give up my selfish tendencies to accommodate her needs. It comes back to control and trust. I have a very difficult time giving those things up. As I learn to rely on her and give trust and control over to her, it allows me to bond more with her. Admittedly, this is very, very difficult to do. I still think crooked thoughts despite zero reasons to. It’s me and my world that I am projecting on to the relationship, not her. I think this is where many sociopaths think, “Screw this, it’s getting too close, I’m out. It’s not worth it.”. I have joked in the past that if she betrayed I would ____ her. The ultimate betrayal would hurt deeply. It wouldn’t end me. It would likely kill off what traces of hope I have left in humanity. Can a sociopath love? I think this picture says it all.  The branch represents our pruned pro social emotional neural pathways. The bloom represents our capacity for love should we place ourselves in the right situation, with the right person, and give our relationship the right attention it deserves. The capacity is there. We are human. The better question is: will a sociopath place themselves in a (vulnerable) position to find and cultivate love? It’s taken me many years to learn the love. Pretty sure I wouldn’t be ready to do this again any time soon should I become single once again. Yet, the capacity is there, so who knows? I will say having a life partner who understands you beats dating and banging chicks that you know won’t be around or that you don’t intend to keep around. So we can love so long as we choose to love.

That is an interesting question. Sociopaths typically lack empathy, which is at least one of the prerequisites for a loving relationship. Real attachments are difficult for them since they tend not to have the same range of emotion as someone who is “neurotypical”. Sociopaths are mostly quite self-aware and many suffer with the awareness that they will never feel the intense loving emotions that other people feel. I would think a sociopath could form bonds with someone who shared the same views and goals, and he/she might be quite protective and committed, but for reasons different than love and caring. The relationship might be otherwise beneficial, as in shared income, regular sex, someone to talk to; or the sociopath may want or need the appearance of normalcy for some reason. Statistically, sociopaths do not tend to form successful, loving, long-term relationships. But all sociopaths, now and forever more? I don’t know. I would like to hear from someone who identifies as a sociopath and who may have done some research on this topic. *Please note I am not a doctor. My views are based on personal experience and informal research.

Something I have not felt since I was a small child….and never for anyone outside of my own relations. That’s not to suggest I couldn’t drop him in a heartbeat, were I to find it to be necessary; and completely shut down anything I may think I feel for him.

No and yes, depends on the kind of love you are asking about. The definition of a sociopath is someone who doesn’t feel sympathy or empathy. To love requires sympathy and empathy. A sociopath objectifies everyone and everything. Love can be felt as in “I love my car” but not the kind of love that typically parents feel for their newborn baby - an unconditional love. A sociopath’s love always has strings attached. Having what people call a “conscious” also requires sympathy and empathy so don’t expect a sociopath to feel bad about their actions. A sociopath feels bad about consequences, not actions. Lastly, a sociopath will say they feel love because they do know one kind of love and aren’t aware there is anything else. It is like the saying “you don’t know what you don’t know”.

Noooope. We are very capable of love both emotionally and cognitively because I believe that love is more than just an emotion, it's a state of mind. What I mean by that is, you can become so close to someone that you'd really not like to think about them not being there (emotional) and you can realise cognitively why someone is so compatible with you for whatever reasons (state of mind). Love for us may not be the same as what neurotypicals feel but it is still love nonetheless. Have I experienced it? Not in a romantic sense but I have love for my closest friend. I don't doubt that I can feel romantic love either but I've yet to meet someone that's worth it. It's just as subjective as with neurotypicals, some of them may be very loving and others may not. It's harder for us to get to that point of being in love but it's certainly not impossible.
